sentence: Stocks were modestly higher Friday following strong earnings results from Microsoft ( MSFT ) and Procter & Gamble ( PG ) offsetting an earnings miss by Amazon ( AMZN ) as well as early pressure on global equities after new jitters rekindled by another Ebola diagnosis in the U.S. After a week of punishing volatility, trading appears to have settled into a dull roar with all of the major indices hugging a narrow range and poised to snap a four-week losing streak.
After the open, Wall Street retreated slightly after a downward revision in August new-home sales but quickly recovered as the most recent month showed slight improvement.

September new home sales rose 1.5% to a seasonally-adjusted annual rate of 467,000, beating expectations for a 460,000 annualized pace.But August home sales were cut by over 7% from the 504,000 annual pace first reported to a revised 466,000 yearly sales.
Stocks had been trading lower in today's pre-market in sympathy with weakness in the European markets amid worries following reports at least 10% of Europe's banks could fail upcoming stress testing.
The U.S. markets also were responding to a doctor in New York last night entering isolated hospital care after contracting Ebola while recently treating patients in western Africa.
Crude oil was down $0.88 to $81.23 per barrel.
Natural gas was down $0.04 to $3.76 per 1 million BTU.
Gold was up $2.20 to $1,231.30 an ounce, while silver was up $0.03 to $17.18 an ounce.
Copper was unchanged at $3.04 per pound.
Among energy ETFs, the United States Oil Fund was down 0.88% to $30.79 with the United States Natural Gas Fund was down 1.64% to $19.20.
Amongst precious-metal funds, the Market Vectors Gold Miners ETF was down 0.28% to 20.49 while SPDR Gold Shares were down 0.21% to $118.28.
The iShares Silver Trust was down 0.11% to $16.48.
